#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Prepare Isinglass
#Text=Isinglass is a gelatin-based glue used as an adhesive in art conservation , for preserving parchment , or as a clarifying agent in alcoholic drinks .
#Text=Although you can purchase prepared isinglass , you can also make it yourself .
#Text=As long as you have 3 days , dried fish swim bladders , and a double boiler , you 'll be able to make your own isinglass .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Soaking the Bladders
#Text=Purchase dried and unclotted sturgeon swim bladders .
#Text=You can purchase sturgeon bladders online or from some artist supply stores .
#Text=Before using the bladders , inspect them to make sure they 're free of blood clots and other large blemishes .
#Text=Hake , cod , or other fish with swim bladders can work as an alternative .
#Text=Sturgeon bladders are , however , most commonly used .
#Text=Put the swim bladders in a container filled with room temperature water .
#Text=The amount of water should be in an approximate 1:10 swim bladder-to-water ratio .
#Text=Place the container somewhere that it can sit undisturbed while the water softens the swim bladders .
#Text=A glass container is ideal so you can keep an eye on the swim bladders while they soak .
#Text=Pour the water and swim bladders into a container with mL markings on the side .
#Text=This will help you pour the water more accurately .
#Text=Soak the swim bladders for 24 hours .
#Text=Let the swim bladders soak for approximately 1 day .
#Text=After 24 hours , the swim bladders should be easily pulled apart and spongy to the touch .
#Text=Cutting the swim bladders into smaller pieces can help the isinglass soak up water .
#Text=Knead the swim bladders into a thick paste .
#Text=Using your hands , work the swim bladders into a paste .
#Text=Continue kneading until the paste is a consistent , doughy texture and contains no larger chunks .
#Text=Leave the swim bladders in the container while you knead them .
#Text=If you have smaller flakes in the paste that you ca n't work out with your hands , do n't worry .
#Text=These inconsistencies will be filtered out after boiling .
#Text=Simmering the Paste
#Text=Set up a double boiler .
#Text=Fill the bottom part halfway with water , then set it on a stovetop burner .
#Text=Place the top part of the double boiler onto the bottom part .
#Text=If you do n't have a double boiler , you can make one as an alternative .
#Text=To make your own double boiler , fill a pot with water and put it over your stovetop .
#Text=Place a thick wooden block in the water .
#Text=Set a glass beaker on top of the wooden block to keep it afloat while you boil the swim bladder paste .
#Text=Fill the glass beaker or double boiler with the swim bladder paste and water .
#Text=This water should be the same water you used to fill the container while the swim bladders soaked .
#Text=Do not add more water , as too much can dilute the paste .
#Text=Let the swim bladder paste simmer at .
#Text=Turn on the stovetop to begin heating the paste .
#Text=Keep the temperature consistent , as overheating the paste can damage its consistency .
#Text=Use a thermometer to monitor the water temperature , checking it every few minutes as needed .
#Text=Keep a glass of cold water on hand to cool the water in the bottom part of the double boiler if necessary .
#Text=Stir the swim bladder paste for 45 minutes .
#Text=Use your thermometer or a spoon to stir the paste for about 45 minutes .
#Text=Continue stirring until the paste completely dissolves and turns the water a milky white color .
#Text=You should stir the swim bladder paste consistently for the entire 45 minutes .
#Text=Filtering and Drying Isinglass
#Text=Filter the isinglass glue through a nylon stocking .
#Text=Place a nylon stocking over the top of a glass container and pour the isinglass glue into it .
#Text=The stocking should catch any residual inconsistencies and help make the glue smooth .
#Text=If you do not have a nylon stocking , you can use a cheesecloth or a coffee filter as an alternative .
#Text=Pour the glue onto a non-stick mylar sheet .
#Text=Place the mylar sheet on a flat surface where it can stay for 1-2 days undisturbed .
#Text=Spread the glue over the mylar sheet with a spoon or spatula to prevent areas of pooling that will take longer to dry .
#Text=As an alternative , you can also pour the isinglass glue in small , even dots .
#Text=This will remove the need to cut the sheet later on .
#Text=Although a mylar sheet is traditional , you can also spread the isinglass over a polyester plastic sheet as an alternative .
#Text=Let the isinglass dry for 12-24 hours .
#Text=Depending on the room 's temperature , drying the isinglass should take between 12-24 hours .
#Text=Leave the isinglass undisturbed while it dries to prevent damaging or contaminating it .
#Text=Set up a plastic cover over the isinglass to keep it away from dust and impurities .
#Text=Cut the dried isinglass into pieces .
#Text=Isinglass is easier to store if you cut it in pieces instead of a large sheet .
#Text=The isinglass pieces should be a size small enough for all of them to fit in your storage container .
#Text=Store the isinglass in an airtight container .
#Text=Isinglass will keep best if tightly sealed in a cool , dry atmosphere like a pantry or cupboard .
#Text=Leave the isinglass in storage until you 're ready to use it .
#Text=If stored correctly , isinglass can keep for up to several years .
#Text=Isinglass is traditionally used for clarifying alcoholic drinks , restoring art , and conserving parchment .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Preparing isinglass should take approximately 3 days .
#Text=Plan ahead to make sure you have isinglass when you need it .
#Text=If you do n't have the time to prepare isinglass , you can also buy it in a prepared form .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Because isinglass is made from fish swim bladders , it is not vegetarian .
#Text=Do not use isinglass to change your wine 's consistency if you 're a vegetarian .
#Text=Things You 'll Need
#Text=Sturgeon , hake , or cod
#Text=swim bladder
#Text=Water
#Text=Glass beaker
#Text=Double boiler
#Text=Thermometer
#Text=Spoon
#Text=Nylon stocking
#Text=Non-stick mylar sheet
#Text=Plastic cover
#Text=Sharp knife or scissors
